text:
Our neighborhood is within walking distance to one of the largest private universities.
One can take a leisurely walk, all down hill, and be on campus within 30 minutes.
Consequently, we have a great deal of neighbors that teach at that school.
Mathematics, English, Counseling Psychology, Engineering, Family History, Public Health, and Economics.

When one of them teaches on Sunday, an interesting dynamics is realized.
The class members, ranging from newlyweds to retirees are transformed into students.
The competition for answers is fierce.
The level and the depth is both intense and insightful.
On some days, one wonders if this is a neighborhood, 2nd hour class or a graduate class, with a pre-requisite, taught by one of the neighbors that are also professors.

The first writing assignment of the semester.

Write about a time that you gave something of value away, other than time.

What do I value?
We don’t know its value until it is gone.

The professor brought the discussion back to topic.

Although difficult, suspend judgments, and train ourselves to see others as God sees us.

Another professor/teacher asked a simpler question.

Why church?

Diverse answers came fast,

for congregational learning
preventing drifting
joint goals
opportunities to serve
provide an organization

Then came this,
Justification vs. Sanctification and
Righteousness vs Holiness

I am uplifted by attending a neighborhood gathering on Sundays.
It is part of established spiritual home, a legacy of my parents.
I have witnessed my parents’ lives.
They lived a simple, god fearing (revering) and a life of serving fellowmen.
At times the gospel seems to be complex with some incomprehensible teachings.
I feel like the person mentioned in the 9th Chapter of John.
25 He answered and said, Whether he be a sinner or no, I know not: one thing I know, that, whereas I was blind, now I see.
I don’t know whether I have given away something of value or all of the reasons for attending churches and congregations.
But I do know one thing, by accepting Christ and following His teachings, I was blind but I am beginning to see things as they are.

title: Money Supply and Inflation
text:
M1 vs. M2 Money Supply: Key Differences and Impact on Inflation
The M1 and M2 money supplies both measure the amount of money circulating in an economy, but they focus on different types of liquidity.






Key Differences Between M1 and M2


Feature
M1
M2




Definition
Includes the most liquid forms of money.
Includes M1 plus less liquid savings instruments.


Components
Currency in circulation, checking accounts, Other liquid deposits
Everything in M1, Savings Accounts, Money Market Accounts, Small Time Deposits (CDs under $100k)


Liquidity
Highly liquid (readily available for transactions)
Less liquid (requires additional steps to access)


Purpose
Used primarily for immediate spending.
Represents money that can be saved but is still accessible.


Volatility
More volatile; reacts quickly to economic changes.
More stable; reflects longer-term savings behavior.








Impact on Inflation

M1 and Inflation:


A rapid increase in M1 often signals rising consumer spending, which can push demand higher and contribute to demand-pull inflation.
Conversely, a sharp decrease in M1 may reflect reduced spending power, which can slow economic growth.


M2 and Inflation:


Growth in M2 is more closely linked to longer-term inflation trends since it reflects both spending and savings behavior.
A sharp rise in M2 may indicate excess liquidity, which can eventually spill into consumer prices.



Example Scenario:

If the Federal Reserve increases the money supply (M1) rapidly, consumers may spend more, driving up demand for goods and services. Without an increase in supply, this can raise prices, causing inflation.
On the other hand, a spike in M2 might show that people are saving more, potentially delaying inflation but signaling future spending capacity.



Key Insight

M1 is a better short-term indicator of spending patterns.
M2 provides a broader view of money growth and its potential long-term impact on inflation.




M1 Supply and Consumer Price Index (CPI)
From Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis

M1 Supply (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/M1SL)
Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items in U.S. City Average (CPIAUCSL) (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL)





























































Does M1 Money Supply Predict Inflation or Vice Versa
The M1 money supply and inflation are closely linked, but the relationship is complex — one does not always predict the other in a straightforward way. Here’s how the interaction generally works:

1. M1 Growth as a Predictor of Inflation

M1 Expansion → Inflation Risk:

When the M1 supply rises rapidly, it often signals increased consumer spending. If demand outpaces the supply of goods and services, demand-pull inflation can occur.
Example: During economic stimulus periods, expanded M1 may lead to higher prices if consumer spending surges.

✅ M1 growth tends to lead inflation — but only if spending activity rises faster than supply.


2. Inflation Influencing M1

Inflation → Higher M1 Demand:

In inflationary periods, consumers may keep more funds in liquid forms (like checking accounts) to cope with rising prices, which can inflate M1 figures.
Example: In times of high inflation, people may reduce savings in long-term deposits (M2) and instead hold more cash or liquid assets (M1) to maintain spending flexibility.

✅ Inflation can increase M1 as people adjust financial habits.


3. Situations Where the Link Breaks

Velocity of Money: If M1 rises but money velocity (the rate money circulates in the economy) falls, inflation may not follow.
Supply Chain Factors: Inflation can also spike due to supply-side shocks (e.g., oil crises, labor shortages) without direct M1 changes.



Historical Example:

2020–2021 (Pandemic Stimulus Era):
The U.S. M1 supply surged due to stimulus payments and loose monetary policy.
Initially, inflation remained low because consumers saved more and spent cautiously.
By late 2021, when spending increased, inflation spiked sharply.




Conclusion:

M1 growth is often a leading indicator of inflation, but its predictive power depends on consumer behavior, economic conditions, and supply-side factors.
Inflation can also reshape M1 patterns as people shift toward more liquid assets

Open AI Explanation of Special Relativity
The difference in years for an astronaut traveling at near-light speed and then returning to Earth is explained by Einstein’s Theory of Relativity, specifically Special Relativity and the concept of time dilation.

Key Concept: Time Dilation
Time dilation means that time passes at different rates for observers moving relative to each other. According to Einstein’s Special Relativity:

As an object moves faster, time slows down for it relative to an observer at rest.
The effect becomes dramatic as the object approaches the speed of light.



The Thought Experiment: The Twin Paradox
Imagine a twin astronaut traveling on a spaceship near the speed of light (say, 99.9% of the speed of light) and then returning to Earth.

During the journey:

The astronaut’s clock (inside the spaceship) runs much slower compared to a clock on Earth.
To the astronaut, time feels normal, but for observers on Earth, the astronaut is aging much more slowly.

When the astronaut returns to Earth:

Because time was moving slower for the astronaut, they may have aged only a few years.
Meanwhile, much more time has passed on Earth—possibly decades or even centuries.




Why It Happens

Space and time are not absolute; they are interconnected in spacetime.
High speeds cause space contraction and time dilation, effects predicted and confirmed by relativity.



Conclusion
If an astronaut were to travel at near-light speeds for what feels like a few years for them, they could return to Earth and find that many more years (even centuries) have passed here. This is a real effect and has been experimentally confirmed using high-speed particles and precise atomic clocks.

The story of how Rebekah was chosen as a wife for Isaac by Abraham’s servant is found in Genesis 24. Here’s a summary:

Abraham’s Mission for His Servant
Abraham, now old, wanted his son Isaac to marry someone from his homeland rather than a Canaanite woman. So, he sent his most trusted servant (traditionally thought to be Eliezer) to Mesopotamia, to the city of Nahor, where his relatives lived. He made the servant swear to find a wife for Isaac from Abraham’s own people and not from the local Canaanites.


The Servant’s Prayer for Guidance
When the servant arrived at a well outside the city, he prayed to God for a sign. He asked that when he asked a young woman for a drink of water, she would not only give him water but also offer to draw water for his camels. This, he believed, would be a sign that she was the right wife for Isaac.


Rebekah’s Kindness and God’s Sign
Before the servant even finished his prayer, Rebekah—the granddaughter of Abraham’s brother, Nahor—came to the well. When the servant asked her for a drink, she eagerly gave him water and also offered to draw water for his camels, just as he had prayed! Since camels can drink a lot, this act showed her kindness, generosity, and hardworking nature.


The Servant’s Confirmation and Gifts
Amazed, the servant asked who she was. When he learned she was from Abraham’s family, he bowed and thanked God for guiding him. He then gave Rebekah gold jewelry as gifts.


Rebekah’s Family Approves the Marriage
The servant went to Rebekah’s home and explained his mission to her family. Her brother Laban and her father Bethuel agreed that this was God’s will and allowed Rebekah to go with the servant to marry Isaac. Rebekah herself agreed, showing her faith and willingness to follow this destiny.


Rebekah and Isaac’s Marriage
Rebekah traveled back with the servant to Canaan. When Isaac saw her, he took her into his mother Sarah’s tent and married her. The Bible says he loved her, and she became a comfort to him after his mother’s death.

There are several types of audits, each serving different purposes depending on the industry, compliance requirements, and organizational goals. Here’s a breakdown of the main types of audits:


1️⃣ Financial Audit
📌 Purpose: Ensures the accuracy and fairness of financial statements.

📌 Conducted by: External auditors (e.g., CPA firms) or internal auditors.

📌 Example: A company undergoes an annual audit by an external accounting firm to comply with regulations.



2️⃣ Internal Audit
📌 Purpose: Evaluates internal controls, risk management, and operational efficiency.

📌 Conducted by: Internal auditors employed by the organization.

📌 Example: A company’s internal audit team reviews payroll processes to detect errors or fraud.



3️⃣ Compliance Audit
📌 Purpose: Ensures adherence to laws, regulations, and industry standards.

📌 Conducted by: Government agencies, regulatory bodies, or independent auditors.

📌 Example: A hospital is audited for HIPAA compliance to ensure patient data security.



4️⃣ Tax Audit
📌 Purpose: Verifies the accuracy of tax filings and compliance with tax laws.

📌 Conducted by: Tax authorities (e.g., IRS, state tax agencies).

📌 Example: The IRS audits a business to check for proper tax deductions and income reporting.



5️⃣ Operational Audit
📌 Purpose: Assesses operational efficiency and effectiveness.

📌 Conducted by: Internal or external auditors.

📌 Example: A manufacturing company undergoes an operational audit to optimize its production process and reduce waste.



6️⃣ IT (Information Systems) Audit
📌 Purpose: Evaluates cybersecurity, data protection, and IT system controls.

📌 Conducted by: IT auditors, cybersecurity specialists, or external consultants.

📌 Example: A bank undergoes an IT audit to ensure customer data is secure from cyber threats.



7️⃣ Forensic Audit
📌 Purpose: Investigates fraud, financial crimes, or misconduct.

📌 Conducted by: Forensic accountants and fraud examiners.

📌 Example: A forensic audit is conducted in a company to uncover embezzlement.



8️⃣ Performance Audit
📌 Purpose: Assesses whether programs or projects are achieving their intended goals efficiently.

📌 Conducted by: Government agencies or internal auditors.

title: Survive Thrive
text:
Although my parents didn’t give many direct lessons on life, I have learned aplenty.
If I had to summarize their life’s teaching and motto in one word, it would be,

Survive

They taught by living their life fully each day.
There are times when the life seems too complicated and full of worry.
Think through what they went through and didn’t complaint
They didn’t murmur

Father passes away at 35, takes care of 4 younger siblings, link
Captured and escapes as POW, early 20s, 3 times, link
At 19, the family escapes North Korea on a boat, in January. link
Start a new life in America, in mid-40s, link
Work in a war-zone, as 30-something, link

Growing up, hearing these stories were not impactful - immediately
However, I remembered the stories because they were given and received as teaching moments.
These recollections form the foundation of who they were and how I should emulate them.

When my mother was 39 she studied and accepted a new religion.
She had been a Christian all her life.
She joined the church, then 말일성도 예수그리스도 교회.
Now 예수그리스도 후기성도 교회.
The acceptance of the Gospel and its abundant approach to life fit my parents’ life.
Also the concept of temple worship and the eternal binding of family must have appealed to them.
They had both temporal foundation and eternal foundation.
When challenges came, they solved it based on their earthly experience and the heavenly perspective.


Thus when trials come these days, I do not think of escape as I once did.
I think of my parents, and wonder how they would have handled it.
The answer comes, quietly and reassuringly.

Be still, and know that I am God
Psalm 46:10

For I know the plan and the purpose of this life.
To walk the path that leads to eternal life.
The same path that my parents took, without murmuring.
The one they took on with a full faith and a measure of joy.
They struggled to survive, but thrived in their latter years.

Thank you Mom and Dad.

Japanese team suggested multiple years. Our team thought few weeks was sufficient.

Elements of a family legacy
Family legacy refers to the values, traditions, achievements, or assets passed down through generations. It can take many forms—tangible or intangible—and often shapes a family’s identity and sense of purpose.


📜 Examples of Family Legacy

1. Cultural Traditions

Celebrating holidays in a specific way (e.g., Chuseok or Thanksgiving with certain rituals).
Passing down traditional recipes, language, or dress.



2. Inherited Values or Beliefs

A strong work ethic or emphasis on education.
Religious or spiritual traditions followed across generations.
Commitment to community service or generosity.



3. Professional or Craft Heritage

A family of doctors, farmers, artists, or teachers, where skills and professions are passed down.
For example, generations of potters or calligraphers in Korea or Japan.



4. Storytelling and Family History

Sharing tales of grandparents’ immigration, war experiences, or sacrifices.
Maintaining a family tree or archive.



5. Property and Heirlooms

A house or land handed down through generations.
Heirlooms such as a wedding ring, Bible, or handmade items with sentimental value.



6. Business Legacy

Design controls are structured processes that manufacturers must follow during the development of medical devices. The goal is to ensure devices meet user needs, intended uses, and regulatory standards, minimizing risks and improving quality.

Design and Development Planning


Define responsibilities, timelines, and milestones.

Maintain a Design and Development Plan and update as needed.



Design Input


Translate user needs and intended use into measurable design requirements.

Must be reviewed and approved.



Design Output


Document the final design specifications (drawings, production specs, etc.).

Must be traceable to design inputs.



Design Review


Formal, documented reviews at various development stages.

Involve cross-functional teams to evaluate progress and identify issues.



Design Verification


Confirm that the design outputs meet the inputs (e.g., functional testing).

“Did we build the product right?”



Design Validation


Ensure the device meets user needs and intended uses under real or simulated conditions.

“Did we build the right product?”



Design Transfer


Transition design into manufacturing specifications for consistent production.



Design Changes


All design changes must be reviewed, validated/verified, and documented.



Design History File (DHF)


A complete record showing how the design was developed, reviewed, and validated.

A Fiber Optic Gyroscope (FOG) is a crucial component in missile navigation systems, providing highly accurate angular velocity measurements to ensure precise guidance and control. Here’s how it works and why it’s used:

How a FOG Works
A Fiber Optic Gyroscope operates based on the Sagnac Effect, which is an optical phenomenon where light traveling in opposite directions through a coiled fiber experiences a phase shift when the system rotates. The key components include:


Coiled Optical Fiber – Light is transmitted through several kilometers of fiber optic cable wound in a coil.

Laser Source – A laser beam is split into two and sent in opposite directions through the fiber coil.

Interference Detection – When the missile rotates, a phase shift occurs between the two light beams due to the Sagnac Effect, which is measured to determine angular velocity.




Why FOGs Are Used in Missile Navigation


High Accuracy – FOGs provide precise rotational data, crucial for guiding missiles toward their targets.

No Moving Parts – Unlike traditional mechanical gyroscopes, FOGs are solid-state, making them more reliable and durable.

Fast Response Time – Optical signals are processed almost instantly, allowing real-time adjustments to missile trajectory.

Resistant to External Disturbances – They are less affected by vibrations, accelerations, and electromagnetic interference, which are common in missile environments.

Long Operational Life – Due to their solid-state nature, they have a longer lifespan and lower maintenance requirements.




Application in Missile Systems
FOGs are integrated into Inertial Navigation Systems (INS), which track a missile’s position without relying on external signals like GPS. This makes them especially useful in:

Ballistic Missiles – Ensuring precise long-range targeting.
Cruise Missiles – Providing accurate navigation for terrain-following and target-seeking.
Air-to-Air and Surface-to-Air Missiles – Enhancing mid-course and terminal guidance.

Here are several examples where the originator of significant ideas or teachings did not write them down directly, but their disciples or followers preserved and transmitted their teachings:

Socrates (c. 470–399 BCE)

Writings by: Plato, Xenophon

Socrates never wrote down his own philosophy. His ideas survive through the works of Plato (e.g., The Republic, Apology) and Xenophon.

Confucius (551–479 BCE)

Writings by: His disciples

The Analects is a collection of Confucius’ sayings and ideas compiled by his followers after his death.

Buddha (Siddhartha Gautama) (c. 563–483 BCE)

Writings by: Buddhist monks and disciples

Buddha’s teachings were passed down orally for centuries before being written down in texts like the Tripitaka.

Jesus of Nazareth (c. 4 BCE–30 CE)

Writings by: His apostles and early followers

The New Testament was written by apostles such as Paul, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John.

Muhammad (570–632 CE)

Writings by: His companions (Sahaba)

The Quran was compiled after Muhammad’s death based on his recitations memorized and recorded by his followers.

Pythagoras (c. 570–495 BCE)

Writings by: Pythagorean school members

Pythagoras himself left no writings; his ideas are known through later thinkers like Philolaus and others.

Laozi (Lao Tzu) (c. 6th century BCE)

Writings by: His followers

While the Tao Te Ching is attributed to Laozi, some scholars believe it was compiled by disciples.

Francis of Assisi (1181–1226 CE)

Writings by: His followers

Many of his teachings were transmitted through works like The Little Flowers of St. Francis.

Ramakrishna (1836–1886 CE)

Writings by: Swami Vivekananda and other disciples

His philosophy and spiritual insights were preserved in texts like The Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna.


These instances highlight how influential figures often relied on oral traditions, with followers later documenting their ideas.

✝️ Easter Date Determination
Easter is celebrated on:

The first Sunday after the first full moon on or after the vernal equinox
(fixed as March 21 in church calculations)


Step-by-step:

Identify March 21 (ecclesiastical spring equinox).
Find the first full moon (called the Paschal Full Moon) after March 21.
Easter is the following Sunday.


This is based on the Gregorian calendar (used in Western Christianity).

Eastern Orthodox Easter uses the Julian calendar, which often results in a different date.

title: Passover then Easter
text:
✡️ Passover Date Determination
Passover begins on:

The 15th day of the Hebrew month of Nisan, which is based on the Jewish lunisolar calendar.


Details:

Nisan begins with the new moon closest to the spring equinox.
Passover always begins at sundown on 15 Nisan.
It often falls on or near the full moon, just like Easter, but is based on the Hebrew calendar, not the Gregorian one.



Duration:

7 days in Israel
8 days in the diaspora (for traditional Jews)

title: Passover then Easter
text:
📅 Relationship Between the Two
Easter often falls during or shortly after Passover, because the crucifixion of Jesus is described as occurring during Passover.
However, due to different calendar systems and adjustments (e.g., leap months in the Jewish calendar), the two don’t always align.


🔁 Patterns and Exceptions
The Jewish calendar occasionally adds a leap month (Adar II) to stay in sync with the solar year. This can shift Passover later, causing Easter to occur before Passover in rare years.
The Council of Nicaea (325 AD) fixed the method for calculating Easter, decoupling it from the Jewish calendar, which is why the dates are similar but not identical.

A camera sensor is the electronic component inside a digital camera that captures light coming through the lens and converts it into an image.
Think of it like the digital version of film in old cameras.

title: Similar Outcome
text:
🔍 How It Works:

Light enters through the lens.
It hits the sensor, which is covered with millions of tiny light-sensitive units called photosites or pixels.
Each pixel measures the amount of light and color that hits it.
The sensor sends this data to your camera’s processor, which turns it into a digital image.
